thread.title: McMenamins Anderson School Main Lodge features 72 guest rooms
thread.title_full: McMenamins Anderson School Main Lodge features 72 guest rooms | OregonLive.com

author: Terry Richard | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: McMenamins Anderson School Main Lodge features 72 guest rooms
text:
The bells no longer signal class changes at Anderson School, but you can still be summoned to the Principal's Office.
If that happens, it's likely because a friend wants to meet you there for morning coffee, or perhaps for a nightcap.
Built in 1931 and operated as a junior high, Anderson School is looking better than ever following its renovation and reopening as the 72-room hotel at McMenamins Anderson School entertainment complex in Bothell, Wash., a northeast suburb of Seattle.
The McMenamin brothers of Portland specialize in preserving these kinds of properties and breathing new life into them, as evidenced by three of their biggest successes in Oregon: Edgefield at Troutdale, Kennedy School in Northeast Portland and Grand Lodge in Forest Grove.
Anderson School is right there among the best showcases of the McMenamins empire, which includes a chain of some 65 hotels, pubs and music venues in Oregon and Washington, with most of them in the greater Portland area. Anderson School is central to the on-going revitalization of downtown Bothell.
The red brick classroom, built in Art Deco style, operated as the area's main junior high from 1931 to 1965, then was used as an overflow school until 1973. The Northshore School District ran it aa a secondary alternative school until the City of Bothell purchased it in 2009, in partnership with McMenamins.
Renovation of the grounds has been ongoing, in a project of more than $26 million, until the entertainment complex celebrated its grand opening last weekend.
Called the Main Lodge, the hotel is not attached to the other buildings but is a short walk away across the compound to the restaurants, bars and swimming pool. The 72 guest rooms are served by the Principal's Office on the third floor, a small space for dispensing drinks and snacks daily from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Each of the guest rooms is well appointed with bedding and lightning fixtures, similar to McMenamins Gearhart Hotel on the Oregon coast, is decorated with quirky McMenamins art and has full bathroom facilities. Rates begin at $155 per night, plus tax.
Rooms are on three floors, with the upper floors retaining 12-foot ceilings. An elevator at the south entry provides handicap access. Registration is at the hotel front desk, inside the building with the Tavern on the Square restaurant and a short walk from the north entrance of the hotel.
The grassy strip east of the hotel won't be there for long, because the city of Bothell has plans to reroute part of Bothell Way onto it. There will remain a European-style boulevard between Bothell Way and the hotel, which is a narrow, driveable lane of brick pavers that has curbside parking and access to McMenamins parking lots.
McMenamins Anderson School is at 18603 Bothell Way N.E., Bothell; 425-398-0122; mcmenamins.com .
Stay tuned to this website for more on McMenamins Anderson School.
